title: How to Relate
question_text: Which of the following is not able to show a relationship between two quantitative variables?
solution:
Solution

Relationships between quantitative variables can be shown a variety of ways. Associations between these variables may be evident by looking at scatterplots or by using the points on a scatterplot to calculate a linear regression equation. In addition, distributions can be compared to show relationships between variables. For example, histograms and boxplots can be shown side-by-side for a comparison of distributions.

In this problem two-way tables are the exception. These are used to establish relationships between categorical variables.

So, Choice 'E' is correct.

Explanation of Distractors

Choice 'A' is incorrect because a scatterplot can be used to show a relationship between two quantitative variables.

Choice 'B' is incorrect because comparing two distributions using histograms can be used to show a relationship between two quantitative variables.

Choice 'C' is incorrect because comparing two distributions using boxplots can be used to show a relationship between two quantitative variables.

Choice 'D' is incorrect because linear regression can be used to show a relationship between two quantitative variables.
